speaker: Frasier
text: This is Dr. Frasier Crane, KACL, 780.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, that was security.  Some woman insisted on seeing you, she just blew right past them.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't panic, Roz -- probably just one of my more ardent fans.  _Diane Chambers appears in the window and knocks on the glass. Frasier turns around.  She smiles and waves at him.  Focus on Frasier's wide-open mouth: "AAAAAAAAAAAAHHHH!!!!!"  Cut to: Niles's Office Frasier bursts into Niles's office.  Niles is sitting at his desk with a pad.  His patient, a man, is seated in an armchair by the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, we've got to talk!  It's urgent.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I'm with a patient!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_notices man_] Oh, I'm sorry.

speaker: Man
text: Is, uh, this about a woman?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Man
text: Take all the time you need.

speaker: Niles
text: Well?

speaker: Frasier
text: She's back -- the scourge of my existence.

speaker: Niles
text: Strange, I usually get some sign when Lilith is in town -- dogs forming into packs, blood weeping down the wall.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm talking about . . . Diane Chambers.

speaker: Niles
text: Lucille, send Mr. Carr home.

speaker: Frasier
text: She just showed up at the station today.  Apparently some play she wrote is being produced here in town.  I admit, I just sort of panicked when I saw her, but I think I covered it masterfully.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right, all right.  Well, uh, why do you think you reacted that way?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, spare me the psychiatrist bit, Niles.  That includes putting down the pad! [_Niles lays the pad on the desk_] In the drawer, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: [_puts it in the drawer_] Fine.  My first question to you is this: Are you still in love with her?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_jumps up from his chair_] No!  Not in the least!  It's a ridiculous suggestion.

speaker: Niles
text: Seeing as how I have nowhere to write the phrase, "classic denial," I'll move on.  So, about this woman for whom you have so little feeling that you raced across town and burst into one of my sessions--is there any lingering resentment?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_dropping back into the chair_] Over what?!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, she did leave at the altar.  When you told her how that made you feel, was there anything you left unsaid? [_Frasier looks away_] Any phrase or feeling you wished you had expressed to her? [_Frasier looks away more_] I'm making the assumption here that you did tell her how you felt.

speaker: Frasier
text: I sort of did.

speaker: Niles
text: "Sort of" is another one of those phrases that just wants to go in my pad.

speaker: Frasier
text: I expressed my distaste for the way I'd been treated, yes.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, she rejected you in the most debilitating way a man can be rejected.  You've got to more than "sort of" tell her how that felt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I can't just tell Diane how awful she made me feel now!  It's a distant memory for her.  I'd feel weak!

speaker: Niles
text: You have no reason to feel weak.  You've moved on in your life too.  You have a new career, new wealth, new success. You simply need closure in this one area.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, what you just said made a lot of sense.

speaker: Niles
text: You're going to get closure.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, that business about my success!  I tuned you out after that.  I'm going to invite Diane over for dinner tonight, and I'm really gonna flaunt my success, really rub her nose in it!  That'll prove I'm not just some cast-aside that never got over her.  Niles, I know it's not psychologically sound.  But we're still human.  We have to do what feels good sometimes, don't we?

speaker: Niles
text: I'd just like to be on the record as saying I'm against it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.

speaker: Niles
text: You know the path that leads to peace with Diane and you're rejecting it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm washing my hands of the entire matter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wouldn't miss it for the world though, would you?

speaker: Niles
text: I'll be there at seven with a cheeky Bordeaux.  _Frasier leaves.  Niles grabs his pad out of the drawer and starts writing on it.  Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment It's evening.  Daphne is arranging things for dinner.  Martin is reading the paper.  Frasier comes out, wearing his best suit._

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no.  Daphne, I was very specific about this.  The mayor's plaque goes on the piano . . .

speaker: Frasier
text: The Otis Klandenning "Man of the Year Award" goes right over here . . .  _He places an elaborate silver bowl on the little table next to the Armchair._

speaker: Frasier
text: And my jewel--my SeaBee--goes right here where she can't miss it! [_puts in on the mantel_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Hmm, that seems a bit subtle.  Why don't I just use this to serve the olives?  _She takes the SeaBee trophy --a silver miniature of the Space Needle--and spears an olive out of the appetizer tray._

speaker: Frasier
text: Give me that!

speaker: Daphne
text: I wish someone would just tell me who this woman is, and why we're trying to impress the pants off her.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's a one-time Boston barmaid who had a nervous breakdown and ended up in a sanitarium, where I met her, fell for her, and then was so mercilessly rejected by her that to this day there is a sucking chest wound where once there dwelled a heart!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_welcoming_] Diane!

speaker: Diane
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please. [_she comes in_] You remember my brother Niles, my father Martin, and this is his health-care worker, Daphne Moon.

speaker: Diane
text: What a tasteful abode.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's modest in its way.

speaker: Diane
text: No, that's what I like about it.  After the rambling beach house I've been living in, I'm ready for something smart and efficient.

speaker: Frasier
text: White wine, Diane?  I'm pouring an '85 Montrachet La Guiche I purchased at auction.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, I always keep a bottle of that open myself.  _Frasier's smile is so fixed on his face, it's painful to look at.  He tosses her coat to Daphne._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hang this up!

speaker: Diane
text: Well, Martin, it's been too long.  How have you been?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, my wife died, I got shot in the hip, and I had to move in with Frasier 'cause I kept falling down in the shower.

speaker: Diane
text: Well, you look wonderful! [_pats his leg_] Yes, you do!

speaker: Martin
text: That's the bad one.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh! [_gets up_] Niles, do you remember the last time I was in town and we dined together?  You had just started dating this woman--she was the queerest little creature. [_Frasier hands her a glass of wine_] Thank you. [_laughs_] She ate everyone's sorbet, and then she had to lie down in the ladies' lounge while the coat-check girl massaged her abdomen!

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, I hope I haven't put my foot in it.  You and she didn't get married and live happily ever after, did you?

speaker: Niles
text: No, can't say as we did.

speaker: Daphne
text: Care for an olive?

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: These are a Pyreenean taste treat!  They're handpicked and bottled by Andalusian monks!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_lifting the "Man of the Year" cup_] You can spit the pits in here.  _Frasier snatches the cup down as Diane spits, narrowly missing Martin.  Scene Three -- Frasier's Apartment Everyone is sitting at the dinner table.  Diane is telling a story._

speaker: Diane
text: So, there I was, on the balcony of my Malibu beachhouse, when a pod of whales passed by.  I knew I had to commune with these gentle giants, so like a flash, I was on the beach, scrambling to my kayak.  But cruel fortune interceded, when, not twenty yards offshore, I suddenly discovered myself entangled in an enormous bed of-of, um--

speaker: Niles
text: Sea kelp?

speaker: Diane
text: Exactly right, sea kelp!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's funny--I thought he said "seek help."

speaker: Daphne
text: So, you haven't told us how you've come to be in Seattle.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, a small theater group has decided to produce a play I've written.

speaker: Frasier
text: Which one?

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, my most recent work.  It's a sort of feminist odyssey, experimental in places, in tone akin to Saroyan, with a soupcon of Gide, and a hearty nod to Clifford Odesse!

speaker: Frasier
text: I meant which theater?

speaker: Diane
text: Oh!  The Roundabout.

speaker: Martin
text: That seems appropriate.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, why don't you people just keep talking amongst yourselves?  I will go and fetch the profitteros.  They were prepared by the hottest new pasty chef in--oh, what's the use?

speaker: Niles
text: I'll help.  He always overpowders.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I'm sure Old Man Kennedy felt this kind of pride when his boys would go out and play touch football.  _In the kitchen, Frasier takes a plate of little cakes out of the refrigerator._

speaker: Niles
text: Now, Frasier, you know her better than I.  Is that what she looks like when she's writhing in envy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, shut up.  All right, I admit you were right.  Before she leaves here tonight, I am going to tell her how much pain she made me feel. [_energetically sprinkling sugar on the cakes_] The savage truth this time--there will be no sugarcoating it!  And yes, I am aware of the irony! [_blows a puff in Niles's face_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, it must be wonderful to see your words come to life like that.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh yes.  It's a dream come true.

speaker: Martin
text: Diane, are you o.k.?

speaker: Diane
text: Yes, I'm fine.  Why?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, your cheek was kind of twitching.

speaker: Diane
text: It was?  Oh well, it was probably fatigue.  Where were we?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I was asking about your play.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, right! [_she twitches again, harder_]

speaker: Martin
text: There it goes again, the twitch!

speaker: Daphne
text: That was either a very large twitch or a very small seizure.

speaker: Diane
text: You know, I'm not sure how much I really want to talk about my play right now. [_twitches even harder, and covers her face with a napkin_] Bad luck and all that!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and we all know what a struggle it is to get Diane to talk about herself.

speaker: Diane
text: [_laughing_] Oh Frasier, you always could kid! How I miss that!  _Her laughs slide gradually into tears, and then into noisy, full- blown sobbing._

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, Diane, please, I-I really didn't mean anything by it. I'm sorry--

speaker: Diane
text: It's not that!  It's my whole life, it's ruined!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, could you please get her some water?

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, of course. [_goes to the kitchen_]

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, everything I told you tonight is a lie.  I'm sorry for this.  Oh, I must look just awful.

speaker: Martin
text: Your cheek stopped jumping.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, now.  Tell me what happened.  Was it about your play?

speaker: Daphne
text: There it goes again!

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, would you people please just give us some privacy?!  _Everyone gets up and goes to the kitchen.  Frasier sits next to Diane._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right now.  From the beginning.

speaker: Diane
text: Well, it all started a few months ago when I lost my job. I'd been writing for "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman."  I was on the set one day, and I was trying to show Jane Seymour the proper way to cauterize a wound with a branding iron, and I accidentally set her hair on fire.  Well, from there it was a steady slide downhill.  A two-year relationship ended, I lost the beachhouse, friends stopped calling--the one bright spot was my play in Seattle.  Well, I flew up here yesterday only to find that the backer was pulling out.  I was so distraught I found myself wandering around the city in complete despair.  It's then that like a ray of hope from heaven, I saw your smiling face on the side of a bus.  And that's why I'm here today.  You helped me the only other time I was this low.  Frasier, I'm asking for your help again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course I'll help you, Diane.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, Frasier . . .

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, that was a bit scary.

speaker: Martin
text: I'll say--watching someone go completely crackers like that.

speaker: Martin
text: What's the matter with you now?

speaker: Niles
text: Nothing, I'm fine.  Just suddenly missing my Maris.  _Daphne puts an arm around his shoulder and comforts him.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_ **INTERPLAY**  _Scene Four -- Cafe Nervosa Niles is seated at a corner table.  Frasier comes in.  Throughout the followng scene, Niles never says a word._

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, Niles, it's such a glorious day!  I walked all the way here.  Thirty-two blocks, and Bruno Mallies be damned! [_sits down_] Oh yes, I see the look, I know exactly what it means too.  How could I very well say "no" to Diane?  She came to me in crisis. [_to a passing waitress_] Oh, excuse me, a double cappuccino, please, light cinnamon, thank you very much. [_sighs_] Oh, you know, the change in Diane has really been quite gratifying.  Dropped her off at the theater today, and there was a smile on her face that I haven't seen in . . . well, far too many years.  Oh, I know what you're thinking.  Where did she get the money to do the play? Well, she found a backer! [_pause_] It's tax deductible! [_the waitress brings his coffee_] Thank you.  Oh, why don't you go ahead and say what you're thinking, Niles?  That I'm falling for her again.  "Well, you did bounce in here as though you were on top of the world, and babbling about her smile"--I just don't want to hear it, Niles!  I'm simply helping her to get back on her feet and out of my life as quickly as possible.  No, I don't know how long it's going to take. Look, I said I don't know! Oh, really, Niles!  Curse you, you are the most infuriating busybody!  I'm not sitting with you.  _Frasier gets up and goes to another table.  Niles takes a little pad out of his jacket and starts writing._  **FOREPLAY** _Scene Five -- Frasier's Apartment That evening, Diane and Frasier are standing next to each other, looking out at the city._

speaker: Diane
text: It really is a lovely city.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Night--making all things dimly beautiful . . ."

speaker: Diane
text: "One veil over us both."  Cyrano?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Eleven years later, we're still on the same page.

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier, these past few weeks, you've given so much of yourself to me.  I want to give the one gift I have to bestow.  I want you to be the first person to see my play. Will you come to dress rehearsal tonight?

speaker: Frasier
text: Diane, I'd be honored?

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, wonderful, wonderful!

speaker: Diane
text: Give me a second.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you sure you're ready for this?

speaker: Diane
text: Oh yes, it's time.  Tonight, I bare myself to you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Big step, Diane.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh well, I have to say I'm a little nervous about it.  But, barring any lighting or prop problems, the whole thing will be over in a couple of hours.

speaker: Martin
text: [_heading to the kitchen_] Hello!  People still in the house here!

speaker: Diane
text: Meet me at the theater at seven . . . I don't know what I've done to deserve you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Listen, it's none of my business, but you're not falling for her again, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: What if I were?

speaker: Martin
text: That woman dumped you at the altar.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that was the old Diane.  She no longer sees herself as the center of the universe.  And I'm not the old Frasier anymore either.  People can change, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I suppose you're right.  Take me for instance.  The old Martin would have said, "you're out of your mind.  I'd rather see you go gay and shack up with the punk who shot me than go off with her.  I'd rather see you sewed up inside the body of a dead horse."  But the new Martin just says, "Vivia l'amour."

speaker: Frasier
text: The new Frasier resists the temptation to correct your French.  _Scene Six -- Theater Frasier sits alone in the rows of a small theater.  Diane comes out from behind the curtain and speaks to the whole room._

speaker: Diane
text: Well, the stage is set, my players are prepared.  So, without further ado, I give you "Rhapsody and Requiem," a play by Diane Chambers.  _Frasier applauds.  Diane goes backstage.  The curtain opens.  On the stage is a nearly-perfect replica of Cheers back in Boston, complete with look-alikes.  Frasier's eyes widen._

speaker: Stan
text: [_Sam look-alike_] Boy, it sure is great having Mary-Ann back. Just wasn't the same when she was gone.

speaker: Clark
text: [_Cliff look-alike_] Yeah, well, you know, uh, recent studies at John Hopkins University revealed that the expression "absence makes the heart grow fonder," is in actuality rooted in scientific bedrock.

speaker: Darla
text: [_Carla look-alike_] Yeah, so's your head.

speaker: Stan
text: Ease up there, Darla.

speaker: Ned
text: Evenin', everybody.

speaker: Stan
text: Hey there, Ned.  What would you say to a beer?

speaker: Ned
text: What's a nice beer like you doing in a face like this?  _Backstage, Diane laughs outrageously at her own joke.  For Frasier, this is getting increasingly weird.  Then his own look alike, Dr. Franklyn Creane, walks in the door._

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: Salutations, all.

speaker: Stan
text: Hey there, Doc.  What can I get you?

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: Ooh, a prickly choice, Stan.  It reminds me of the one the 18th-century wit John Wilkes faced when asked by the Earl of Sandwich whether he expected to die on the gallows or of the pox.  "That depends, sir," he said, "on whether I choose to embrace your principles or your mistress."

speaker: Mary-Ann
text: Evening, people.

speaker: All
text: Mary-Ann!  _Cut to Later: the players are each illuminated by spotlights in turn to give interior lines._

speaker: Stan
text: I pour beer down people's throats.

speaker: Ned
text: I drink it.

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: Our lives are empty.  So what draws our feet here night after night?

speaker: Ned
text: Mary-Ann.

speaker: Mary-Ann
text: Well, I'm off.  See you anon, mi amore.

speaker: Stan
text: [_kisses her_] You bet, honey.

speaker: Diane
text: [_coming onstage_] Hold it, stop!  What kind of a kiss was that? You two are supposed to be in love!

speaker: Stan
text: Well, I didn't know how big you wanted it.

speaker: Diane
text: Remember that kiss you gave me this morning?

speaker: Stan
text: Like this one?  _The actor grabs Diane and kisses her deeply.  Frasier stews with jealousy._

speaker: Diane
text: That's the one.  O.K., from the kiss! [_goes offstage_]

speaker: Stan
text: You bet, honey.

speaker: Mary-Ann
text: Forgive me, Franklyn.  I suppose that was a tad inconsiderate.

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: Quite all right.  A loving spirit like yours can't be bridled.

speaker: Mary-Ann
text: But I did leave you at the altar.

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: No, you know I hold no ill-will toward you for that.

speaker: Dr. Creane
text: Could we just stop for a second?  This whole getting- left-at-the-altar thing--I just don't know what I'm supposed to be feeling.

speaker: Frasier
text: I may be able to illuminate that for you! [_gets up and storms onstage_] What you are feeling is that this woman has reached into your chest, plucked out your heart, and thrown it to her hell-hounds for a chew toy!  And it's not the last time either!  Because that's what this woman is!  She is the devil!  There's no use running away from her, because no matter how far you go, no matter how many years you let pass, you will never be completely out of reach of those bony fingers!  So, drink hearty, Franklin, and laugh!  Because you have made a pact with Beelzebub! And her name is Mary Ann!  _Frasier storms out of the theater.  The rest of the cast members break into applause.  Diane stands there, mortified._  **AFTERPLAY**  _Scene Seven -- Theater Diane is sitting at the bar, alone.  She is making notes on her play script.  Frasier comes back._

speaker: Frasier
text: Diane?

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier . . .

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought we should talk.

speaker: Diane
text: Well, yes, I think we should.  I tried to reach you at your home.

speaker: Frasier
text: I was driving around.

speaker: Diane
text: [_sighs_] I'm sorry if I in any way misled you about my feelings these last few weeks.

speaker: Frasier
text: You didn't.  I think I mislead myself.

speaker: Diane
text: Well, at the very least I obviously owe you an apology for the first time that things went awry between us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's all right.

speaker: Diane
text: No, it was a time in my life when--

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Diane, it isn't necessary.  The things I said . . . well, they just needed saying.  Besides, I don't really feel all that harshly--and in retrospect, I'm reasonably sure that you are not the devil . . . although he does have the power to assume pleasing shapes.

speaker: Diane
text: Well, you should know I've decided to go back to Los Angeles.  Watching the play tonight through fresh eyes, I--well, I just don't think it's ready.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sure things'll work out fine.  Well, I think I've said what I came to say.

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier, um, before you go, there's one last thing you could help me with, not that you haven't helped me a lot already. It's the last scene, where Franklyn and Mary-Ann say goodbye.  It's never felt quite right to me.  I'd like her to stand . . . oh, right about here [_stands in the middle of the stage_] and tell him how much he's meant to her and how she'll never forget him.  How do you suppose . . . "Franklyn" would respond to that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I suppose he'd tell her that he feels the same way. That she's touched him in a way she can never imagine, he's glad she was in his life.

speaker: Diane
text: All that would be left would be the "goodbye."  How do you see that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I suppose he could say, uh, "until we meet again," probably certain that they never would.

speaker: Diane
text: But mightn't there be a part of him that hopes they would?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I suppose so, yes.  All right, then, don't have him sum things up.  Just let them say their goodbyes, and if their paths happen to cross again, so be it . . . Goodbye, Mary Ann.

speaker: Diane
text: Goodbye, Franklyn.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh yes, that's a perfect moment, uncluttered by any extra words or phrases--

speaker: Frasier
text: Diane.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh shoot, I've blown it!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, let's try it again. [_stands toe-to-toe with her_] Goodbye, Diane.

speaker: Diane
text: Goodbye, Frasier.  _They hug.  He goes out the bar door.  She starts to say something, then he comes back through it._

speaker: Frasier
text: Force of habit.

speaker: Diane
text: I've been doing it all week.
